title-group.article-title: Comparison of the quality of life changes of patients receiving sagittal split ramus osteotomy or intraoral vertical subsigmoid osteotomy for mandibular prognathism

contrib-group.aff: grid.194645.b0000000121742757Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, The University of Hong Kong, 34 Hospital Road, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

These permissions are granted for the duration of the World Health Organization (WHO) declaration of COVID-19 as a global pandemic.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To investigate and compare the effect of two orthognathic procedures for mandibular setback, namely, sagittal split ramus osteotomy (SSRO) and intraoral vertical ramus osteotomy (IVRO), on oral health, mental- and physical health-related quality of life across time.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Patients with mandibular prognathism and planned for orthognathic surgery were recruited in this study. Patients were randomized into two groups (IVRO and SSRO groups). Quality of life (QoL) was assessed with the 14-item Short-Form Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14) and the 36-item Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36) preoperatively (T0), postoperative 2 weeks (T1), 6 weeks (T2), 3 months (T3), 6 months (T4), 12 months (T5), and 24 months (T6). A comparison of OHIP-14 and SF-36 scores between two groups was conducted.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Ninety-eight patients (49 SSRO group, 49 IVRO group) participated in this study. There was no significant difference in OHIP-14 scores between SSRO and IVRO throughout the treatment process. SSRO group had significant reduction of OHIP-14 score (i.e., improving oral health–related QoL) since postoperative 2 weeks, whereas IVRO group had significant reduction since postoperative 6 weeks. Starting from postoperative 3 months, the oral health–related QoL of both groups was already significantly better than the baseline level and continued to steadily improve afterwards. For SF-36, both groups had increased physical health summary score starting from postoperative 2 weeks, indicating an early and gradual recovery of physical health–related QoL. The mental health summary score of the SSRO group began to increase from postoperative 2 weeks, but that of the IVRO group only began to increase from postoperative 6 weeks. Patient age at the time of surgery was positively correlated with OHIP scores in the postoperative period.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The study concludes that both SSRO and IVRO contributed to the improvement of QoL in the long term, but oral health– and mental health–related QoL of SSRO groups showed earlier improvement.

sec.title: Clinical relevance
sec.p: Undergoing orthognathic surgery at early ages is advised, as older age of patients appeared to have worse QoL.

sec.title: Trial registration
sec.p: Clinical trial registration number: HKUCTR-1985. Date of Registration: 14 Apr 2015.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2023

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Quality of life (QoL) is a subjective measurement, but essential in providing practitioners insight into patients’ health status related to mental, physical, and social functioning. Changes in perceived health status directly affects treatment satisfaction of patients. When treatment outcome and satisfaction are perceived as personally important in their own life, prolonged life satisfaction will be affected. Thus, this is important to understand the influences of orthognathic surgery on patients’ QoL, so that the gap between expectation of patients and reality can be minimized.

Mandibular prognathism has impacted different aspect of life. In terms of oral functioning, patients with mandibular prognathism would have reduced maximum bite forces and lower masticatory performance, such as difficulty in cutting down foods with central incisors especially if open bite existed [1]. They would have issues with speech, such as difficulty in pronouncing the sounds correctly due to altered tongue posture [2]. In terms of aesthetics, people with class I profiles were perceived as more visually appealing than those with class II or class III profiles [3]. Extensive literature confirmed that individual with attractive appearance would more possibly experience positive evaluation and social interaction than the others [4] Consequentially, they could get a job more easily, and receive more favorable treatment from their employer [5]. In contrast, people with dentofacial problems were often perceived as less visually appealing and less socially accepted by others, rendering them having lower self-esteem and poorer social responses [4, 6, 7]. Surgical correction of mandibular prognathism should restore patients’ physical and psychological well-being and improve their oral health–related QoL. Prior studies evaluated the effects of orthognathic surgery on QoL in general [8], but did not investigate if the effects were affected by different surgical approaches, with the two commonest techniques being intraoral vertical ramus osteotomy (IVRO) and sagittal split ramus osteotomy (SSRO). The former requires 6-week postoperative intermaxillary fixation (IMF), but presented less short-term and long-term morbidity [9] and less surgical relapse [10] compared with the latter.

The purpose of the study was to investigate the effects of two types of orthognathic surgery, namely, IVRO and SSRO, on quality of life of patients with mandibular prognathism. To provide a comprehensive assessment of QoL, two instruments OHIP-14 and SF-36 were employed. These instruments were administered before the surgery and at different times during the 24-month follow-up period. We aimed to reveal if there existed group differences in the overall QoL and various domains assessed by the instruments.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This prospective study is the third part of a larger project investigating the surgical morbidities [9] and skeletal movement [10] of two orthognathic treatments for mandibular prognathism, SSRO and IVRO. This randomized clinical trial was designed and conducted according to the CONSORT 2010 Statement [11]. Ethical approval was granted by the Institutional Review Board (HKU/HA HKW IRB UW 15–132). Written consent was obtained from patients for the use of data analysis.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Patients with mandibular prognathism under reviewed for orthognathic surgery in the Discipline of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, the Prince Philip Dental Hospital, Hong Kong, were invited to participated into the study. Patients were included if they (1) were aged 18 years or older, (2) had stable skeletal growth as shown by serial lateral and frontal cephalometric radiographs obtained 1 year apart, and (3) had planned for mandibular setback surgical procedure as part or all of the orthognathic surgery. Patients with craniofacial syndromes, any systemic condition predisposing them to infection or contraindicating IMF, a history of previous orthognathic surgery, or pre-existing IAN or LN deficit were excluded.

sec.title: Randomization and blinding
sec.p: This was a double-blind randomized controlled trial. A randomization table was generated from a computer by a house officer who was not participating in the study. The allocation sequence was kept concealed in sealed and opaque envelopes with sequential number by a research nurse officer. The sealed envelope was opened by the surgeon once the study consent was obtained. A simple randomization method was used. Eligible patients who were scheduled for orthognathic surgery including a mandibular setback surgical procedure were randomized into one of the study arms: IVRO group and SSRO group. The chance for each recruited patient randomizing into IVRO group and SSRO group was 50/50.

sec.title: Surgical procedures
sec.p: All procedures were performed under a standardized surgical protocol. Patients were randomized to one of the two study intervention arms: IVRO group or SSRO group. Other orthognathic procedures were performed in a routine manner and sequence if indicated. The surgeries were performed under general anesthesia. The surgical procedures used in the two study arms are described below.

In the IVRO group, a vestibular incision was made at the buccal sulcus. A mucoperiosteal flap was raised to expose the lateral ramus. A sigmoid notch retractor and a posterior border retractor were placed for retraction. A vertical osteotomy from the sigmoid notch to the gonion of the mandible was made with an angled oscillating saw. The osteotomy was completed with a curved osteotome. The occlusion was achieved with an acrylic wager. No internal fixation was applied. IMF was secured with wire and custom-made arch bars for 6 weeks postoperative. The wound was closed with resorbable polyglactin sutures.

In the SSRO group, a standardized SSRO procedure with the Dal Pont-Hunsuck modification was performed. After vestibular incision at the buccal sulcus, a mucoperiosteal flap was raised. A short lingual osteotomy bisecting the upper and lower occlusal plane above the lingula was made. The anterior vertical osteotomy was made on the buccal cortex in the molar region. The lingual and buccal osteotomies were joined along the external oblique ridge. The osteotomies were completed with osteotomes and split to separate the proximal and distal segments. The buccal cortex was trimmed for segment adaptation. The occlusion was established with an acrylic wafer. One titanium miniplate was fixed on each side with four screws. The wounds were closed with resorbable polyglactin sutures. Light guiding elastics were used for 3–4 weeks postoperatively.

For both groups, routine medications including analgesics (paracetamol and codeine phosphate if not allergic), antibiotics (penicillin V if not allergic, for 2 days), and steroids (dexamethasone for 2 days) were given. Standard postoperative instructions were given in the same manner to both groups of patients.

sec.title: Outcome measures and time
sec.p: The primary outcomes of the study were the differences of mean overall score of OHIP-14 and SF-36 between IVRO group and SSRO group before operation (T0), postoperatively 2 weeks (T1), 6 weeks (T2), 3 months (T3), 6 months (T4), 12 months (T5), and 24 months (T6). The secondary outcomes were the differences of mean individual domain score of OHIP-14 and SF-36 between IVRO group and the SSRO group at the baseline and different postoperative time point. The effects of gender and age of patients on OHIP-14 and SF-36 scores were investigated.

sec.title: Sample size calculation
sec.p: This study was reporting the QoL findings of the larger project that compared SSRO and IVRO. The project investigated three major aspects between SSRO and IVRO, namely, surgical morbidities, skeletal stability, and QoL. The sample size calculation was based on the expected difference of one of the major surgical morbidities of the two arms of intervention. Following a previous longitudinal study on inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) deficit after various orthognathic procedures [12], the prevalence of an IAN deficit for IVRO and for SSRO was 36.8% and 57.1%, respectively, at postoperative 6 months. With a type 1 error of 5% and power of 80%, 94 sides treated by ramus procedure were required in each group.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The data collection of this study comprised with a package of constructed self-administered questionnaires: (1) oral health status measure, Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14)[13]; (2) general health status (physical and psychological) measure, Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36) [14]; and (3) demographic information. Demographic information was collected at T0, while OHIP-14 and SF-36 were employed at T0, T1, T2, T3, T4, T5, and T6.

sec.title: Short-Form Oral Health Impact Profile Measure (OHIP-14)
sec.p: The OHIP-14 questionnaire was employed to assess the impact oral health condition on well-being. It consists of 14 questions and captures seven domains: functional limitation, physical pain, psychological discomfort, physical disability, psychological disability, social disability, and handicap. Each domain comprises of 2 questions. Patients were asked to rate the frequency of the situation occurred as described with a 5-point Likert scale: 0 = never, 1 = hardly ever, 2 = occasionally, 3 = fairly often, and 4 = very often. The overall OHIP-14 score ranges from 0 to 56, and each of the individual domain score ranges from 0 to 8. A higher score indicates poor QoL. The Chinese version of OHIP-14 was adopted in this study, which was proved to be valid and reliable [13].

sec.title: 36-Items Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36)
sec.p: Psychological and physical well-being were assessed using 36-Items Short Form Survey (SF-36) [14]. The validated Chinese (Hong Kong) version of SF-36 was employed in this study [15, 16]. It consists of eight domains, namely, physical functioning (PF), role physical (RP), bodily pain (BP), general health (GH), vitality (VT), social functioning (SF), role emotional (RE), and mental health (MH). These eight domains derive two summary scores, mental health summary (MCS) and physical health summary (PCS), which indicate the perception of individual mental health and physical health status. The score of MCS, PCS, and each domain ranges from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating better health status.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data were analyzed using IBM SPSS Statistics version 26.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA). The 5% probability was taken as the cut-off for statistical significance. Descriptive statistics were performed to describe the mean score of QoL (i.e., OHIP-14 and SF-36 scores) at different time intervals (T0 to T6). Independent sample t-test was utilized to compare the QoL in various time intervals between IVRO and SSRO groups. Correlation was performed to investigate the relationship of QoL with age and gender. Effect size was calculated by computing the mean group difference, and then divided it by the pooled standard deviation (SD).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
A total of 98 patients (40 males and 58 females, 41% male) with mandibular prognathism planned for orthognathic surgery participated in the study. Patients were randomized into IVRO group (50%) and SSRO group (50%). The demographic information of patients between IVRO group and SSRO group at baseline is shown in Table 1. The mean age of 98 patients was 24.5 years (SD = 3.5, range = 18–33). The mean age was 24.5 in both the IVRO group and SSRO, with SD of 3.6 and 3.5, respectively (p > 0.05). Among the 98 patients, 91% (89/98) were assessed in T1, 91% (89/98) were assessed in T2, 94% (92/98) were assessed in T3, 92% (90/98) were assessed in T4, 91% (89/98) were assessed in T5, and 81% (79/98) were assessed in T6. The reasons of loss to follow-up included loss of contact with the hospital, study abroad, and COVID-19 pandemic.Table 1

sec.title: Longitudinal change of oral health–related QoL in IVRO group and SSRO group (OHIP-14)
sec.p:
The mean (SD) OHIP-14 total scores among 96 patients were 16.3 (8.5) at T0, 23.0 (10.9) at T1, 19.4 (9.9) at T2, 11.8 (8.6) at T3, 9.2 (7.1) at T4, 7.8 (7.5) at T5, and 5.4 (6.2) at T6 (Fig. 1). The pattern of change in OHIP-14 total scores among IVRO and SSRO group were identical, and no significant difference of the OHIP-14 total scores between two groups were observed for each time point. There was a significant increase in OHIP-14 total score (i.e., worsen oral health–related QoL) from T0 to T1 for patients in both IVRO (p = 0.003) and SSRO groups (p < 0.001). Starting from T1, a significant decrease of OHIP-14 total scores for both groups was found (Fig. 1), representing a significant improvement of oral health–related QoL was observed at T1 onwards. The oral health–related QoL of both groups started to become better than pre-treatment at T3 and continue to improve steadily in the late postoperative period until T6.Fig. 1
Change of OHIP-14 mean total score over time between IVRO group and SSRO group

sec.title: Group difference in the change of perceived oral health–related QoL (OHIP-14)
Longitudinal change of psychological and physical health–related QoL in IVRO group and SSRO group (SF-36)
Group difference in the change of perceived psychological and physical–related QoL (SF-36)
sec.p: Throughout the treatment process, significant group difference in the change in PCS and MCS total scores were only found from T1 to T2. SSRO group had a significantly larger increase in PCS (+ 10.0) compared to IVRO group (+ 6.2) (p = 0.032). SSRO group also showed a significantly larger increase in MCS (+ 2.4) compared to IVRO group (− 3.0) (p = 0.011). There was no significant group difference from T2 onwards (Table 4). A few domain scores of PCS and MCS showed group differences. From T1 to T2, SSRO group had a significantly larger increase in domain scores of physical functioning (PF), role-physical (RP), vitality (VT), social functioning (SF), and role-emotional (RE) then IVRO group (p < 0.05).

sec.title: Effect of age and gender on quality of life
sec.p:
No correlation was found between gender of patients and the mean PCS, MCS, and OHIP-14 scores (Fig. 3). However, there were significant correlations of age with OHIP scores, with increased age correlated with increased OHIP-14 score at the following time points: r = 0.23, p = 0.026 at T3; r = 0.23, p = 0.032 at T4; r = 0.26, p = 0.013 at T5; and r = 0.24, p = 0.037 at T6 (Fig. 4).Fig. 3
Comparison of a OHIP-14 and b SF-36 mean total score with genderFig. 4
Correlation between a OHIP-14 and b SF-36 mean total score with age

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study is the first attempt in the literature to compare the oral, physical, and mental impact on patients suffering from mandibular prognathism with two types of orthognathic surgery—IVRO and SSRO. The results of this study indicate that recovery pathway of oral health-related QoL of IVRO and SSRO group were comparatively alike. Patients in both groups experienced an increase of burden in oral health–related QoL at the immediately postoperative period (i.e., T1), and significantly improved by T2. Improvement became stable from T3 onwards. Regarding physical and mental health–related QoL, PCS were declined in both groups from T0 to T1, and started to improve from T1 onward, except that MCS in IVRO group started to improve only from T2 onward meaning that IVRO group had delayed improvement.

As expected, immense reduction in all aspects of QoL (i.e., oral-, mental-, and physical-related QoL) were noted, since surgical complications and discomforts were inevitable [9, 17, 18]. The oral health–related QoL (OHIP-14) of patients in the SSRO group began to improve earlier than IVRO group, likely to be attributed to the 6-week post-surgery intermaxillary fixation (IMF) in the IVRO group. As observed from the longitudinal data, the OHIP-14 score of IVRO patients only started to significantly decrease from T2, consistent to the timing of removing the IMF. The oral health–related QoL in both groups continued to improve in a same manner from T2 onwards, and returned to the baseline level at T3. The process of oral health recovery to the baseline level took 3 months in this study, which was slightly faster than the 6 months reported by some studies [18, 19]. Besides, oral health–related QoL at postoperative 6 months was higher as reported by some other groups [20, 21]. However, it is difficult to compare and draw conclusion on the strength of evidences, as differences in sample size, age, and type of deformity of patients among studies could yield different results.

In terms of physical and mental health–related QoL (SF-36), both PCS and MCS in two groups decreased significantly at T1, but the reduction of PCS was larger than MCS. This indicated that the burden of physical impact was bigger than psychological impact in both groups in early postoperative period. Improvement in physical and mental health–related QoL of patients in SSRO group appeared in T2. However, only improvement of physical health-related QoL was found among patients in IVRO group. Social functioning, emotion, and mental health specifically affected patients in IVRO group. These findings demonstrated that mental health was continuously affected during the IMF period. Normal social functioning, work, and daily activities were interfered by emotional problems. The feelings of nervousness and depress, meanwhile, appeared most of the time as measured by the SF-36 domain scores. Mental health status in IVRO group improved from T2 onwards and returned to the baseline at T3, while physical health status returned to the baseline at T5. The significant reduction in mental health burden from T2 onwards could be explained by the removal of IMF among patients in IVRO. Physical and mental health–related QoL being among patients in SSRO group also returned to baseline level in T6. These finding suggesting that IVRO and SSRO could both improve patients’ physical and mental health in the long term.

Similar with the results reported from previous studies [22, 23], no correlation between gender and QoL was found. However, the reliability of this data may be impacted by the disparity between males and females in the recruited sample. When comparing the QoL with age, a significant positive correlation of age with OHIP-14 scores was found from T3 to T6, with increased age correlated with increased OHIP-14 scores. This indicated that older adults would experience greater burden in oral health–related QoL.

This study facilitates the comparisons between changes in QoL of patients with mandibular prognathism. To provide a more comprehensive picture in understanding the effect of mandibular prognathism after IVRO and SSRO, both clinical oral examination and self-reported oral and general-related QoL are essential. It is important that patients undergoing orthognathic surgery are advised that the structural and functional changes will not only affect physical health, but also mental health. Importantly, patients need to understand that they will experience and need to endure worsened QoL for a short period of time immediately after the surgery. They need to undergo a careful consideration on whether they are willing to endure this in exchange for a long-term improvement.

IVRO, which requires an extended period of IMF, is not favored in many centers in the world, in particular the Western developed countries. The majority of dentofacial deformities in Asia, especially on the Eastern part like Korea, Japan, Taiwan, and our center in Hong Kong, are mandibular prognathism with asymmetry. Because of proven track record of stability and low morbidity for managing asymmetric mandibular hyperplasia, IVRO is still the treatment of choice in many centers in the region. Our center has used both IVRO and SSRO, and sometimes in combination of the two techniques, as the choice for mandibular ramus osteotomies. The choice of which technique to use was mostly surgeons’ preference. This randomized clinical trial is the first in the literature to compare IVRO and SSRO i relation to the patients’ QoL.

In conclusion, orthognathic surgery contributed to the improvement of QoL in the long term. However, patients may need to bear the consequence of deterioration of QoL in the early postoperative period. Several factors such as tolerance levels of the individual, duration of recovery period, and age of undergoing surgery serve to facilitate clinical decision-making for both dental practitioners and patients. Patients appeared to experience more oral and general health burden at early postoperative period after receiving IVRO, but both IVRO and SSRO had similar QoL levels in the late postoperative period. Lastly, undergoing orthognathic surgery at early ages are advised, as older age of patients appeared to have worse QoL.

notes.title: Data Availability
notes.p: The data is available upon request.

notes.title: Ethical approval
notes.p: Ethic approval was granted by the local institutional review board (HKU/HA HKW IRB UW 15–132).

notes.title: Consent to participate
notes.p: Written informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in the study.

notes.title: Consent to publish
notes.p: Patients signed informed consent regarding publishing their data and photographs.

notes.title: Conflict of interest
notes.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
